I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  the  Philippines  through  the  Department  of  Social  Welfare  and 
Development (DSWD) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide policy and 
advisory technical assistance (TA) to (i) support the preparation of a national program for 
scaling up the implementation of community-driven development (CDD), and (ii) for converging 
social protection programs to more effectively reduce poverty and improve living conditions. The 
TA is included in ADB’s 2012–2014 country operations business plan for the Philippines.1 
During the 10–20 April 2012 fact-finding mission, the government and ADB agreed on the TA 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The Philippines is a lower middle-income country with a population of 95.8 million. In 
2011 it had a per capita gross domestic product of $2,346 and a human development index of 
0.644, ranking it 112th out of 187 countries.3 Poverty incidence in the country increased from 
24.9% in 2003 to 26.5% in 2009, while 45% of the population is vulnerable to falling into 
poverty.4 The country is lagging on progress in meeting the Millennium Development Goal 
targets on poverty, education, and maternal health. Spatial inequality is strongly manifested by 
the  significant  differences  in  income  and  poverty  levels  across  regions  and  provinces. 
Disparities in health and education outcomes and inequitable access to basic services and 
development opportunities are also evident in different parts of the country. 
 
3.  The persistence of poverty and inequality in the Philippines has been attributed to low 
public  spending  in  the  social  sector,  a  lack  of  a  coherent  sector  policy  framework,  poor 
coordination, weak service delivery systems, poor targeting and program leakages, lack of 
technical capacities, and inadequate accountability mechanisms. While the Local Government 
Code of 1991 provides the legal basis for improving service delivery at the local level and 
expanding citizens’ participation in devolved functions, the effectiveness of local government 
units (LGUs) in discharging their mandates varies across the country. Local service delivery is 
constrained by several factors, such as (i) unclear and overlapping assignments of service 
delivery functions across tiers of government, with some national government agencies (NGAs) 
continuing to carry out functions that have already been devolved, thus resulting in a multitrack 
system  of  service  delivery,  (ii)  a  weak  system  for  encouraging  and  rewarding  good  LGU 
performance, (iii) high levels of fragmentation among LGUs that reduces the efficiency of basic 
service delivery and inhibits inter-LGU collaboration,5 and (iv) patronage politics and weak 
governance that undermine LGU responsiveness to the needs of the citizens.  
 
4.  CDD approaches have been used by NGAs and development partners in the Philippines 
to augment LGU efforts to improve service delivery and address poverty at the community level. 
Among the key social development programs that apply CDD principles of participatory planning 
and community control of investments is the Kapit-Bisig Laban Sa Kahirapan (Linking Arms to 
Fight  Poverty)—Comprehensive  and  Integrated  Delivery  of  Social  Services  (KC)  program,

managed by the DSWD.6 Studies of the KC program highlight the benefits of the CDD approach, 
which include increased household incomes (as measured by consumption), reduced investment 
costs, and higher economic rates of return.7 In addition, CDD has been found to be effective in 
targeting the poorest barangays (villages) in the poorest municipalities, responding to the needs of 
the people, and lessening the influence of patronage in the allocation of development resources.  
 
5.  The government has recognized the value of the CDD approach as reflected in the 
Philippine  Development  Plan,  2011–2016  and  the  National  Anti-Poverty  Framework,  which 
identify CDD as a core pillar of the country’s overall development program and poverty reduction 
strategy.  The  government  is  scaling  up  CDD  implementation  into  a  national  CDD  program 
(NCDDP) to expand opportunities for poor and underserved communities to choose, design, and 
implement  projects  that  address  their  most  pressing  needs.  Building  on  the  successful 
experiences of the KC program and other CDD programs in the country, the NCDDP will increase 
ongoing  CDD  operations  from  364  municipalities  in  49  provinces  of  12  regions  to  851 
municipalities in 68 provinces of 15 regions. The NCDDP will form part of the government’s 
campaign to converge social development programs to maximize use of resources and create 
more impact to beneficiaries. As such, the NCDDP will be implemented alongside the Building 
Bridges for the Filipino Family Program (Pantawid Pamilya)8 or the conditional cash transfer 
program  and  other  social  development  initiatives  that  promote  job  creation,  livelihood 
opportunities,  and  asset  reform.  The  Human  Development  and  Poverty  Reduction  Cluster 
(HDPRC) has adopted the NCDDP as its flagship project. An NCDDP preparation team in the 
DSWD and an NCDDP interagency preparation team have been created.  
 
6.  Emerging  NCDDP  features  include  (i)  increased  community  capacity  for  project 
implementation and social accountability, (ii) community management of block grant resources, (iii) 
community  monitoring  of  outputs  and  development  outcomes,  (iv)  municipal  LGU  (MLGU) 
oversight of the process, and (v) a more prominent and direct role of provincial LGUs (PLGUs). 
Engagement of PLGUs is envisaged in view of their mandate that includes provision of technical 
assistance, oversight of municipal governance, intermunicipal coordination, and provincial poverty 
targeting. In addition to financing local development projects, PLGUs can strategically promote 
integrated and area-wide development that addresses interregional concerns and the needs of 
geographically isolated areas. At the national level, the Department of the Interior and Local 
Government (DILG) will be expected to provide technical assistance, and monitoring and oversight 
of LGUs. More importantly, the DILG will implement an incentive system to encourage LGUs to 
move progressively towards good governance practices. The National Economic and Development 
Authority  and  the  National  Anti-Poverty  Commission  will  monitor  and  evaluate  the  poverty 
alleviation impacts of the NCDDP. The Department of Finance and the Department of Budget and 
Management will be tasked to facilitate fiscal transfers and undertake overall financial management. 
 
7.  There are however a number of challenges to be faced in the scaling up of CDD. First, 
insofar as CDD approaches have improved income and non-income outcomes, benefits have not

spilled over beyond the project context. Second, the role of PLGUs in CDD implementation has not 
been optimized. Third, the existing policy framework, institutional arrangements, and practices 
inhibit the institutionalization of CDD. Fourth, there is an absence of more stable and longer-term 
funding for CDD activities. Fifth, there are multiple CDD models serving the same population 
groups and this exacerbates inefficiencies in service delivery as well as confusion over competing 
CDD approaches. Sixth, the sizeable geographic coverage and magnitude of the NCDDP will 
strain current systems and require significant structural and operational changes, including capacity 
development. Seventh, there will potentially be resistance from NGAs and LGUs that may perceive 
the NCDDP as an approach that competes with their own service delivery functions and platforms. 
Finally, there is a need to clearly identify options and mechanisms for introducing and managing 
the required reforms for the successful transition and full-scale implementation of the NCDDP. 
 
8.  The TA will therefore assist the government in the conceptualization and design of the 
NCDDP. The TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2020, which aims to reduce poverty and 
promote inclusive growth. It is aligned with ADB’s 2011–2016 country partnership strategy for the 
Philippines, which includes ―more efficient, effective, and equitable delivery of social services‖ as 
one of its four core support areas. The TA will build on ADB’s support to the government in 
addressing  the  lack  of  supply-side  infrastructure  in  the  poorest  municipalities.9 It  will  also 
complement the demand-side interventions of ADB’s support to the government’s social protection 
program by empowering the poor and vulnerable to take control of and manage resources that 
directly affect their welfare, including capacity development of the DSWD, participating LGUs, and 
communities.10 The TA will complement ADB’s support to the government's decentralization and 
local governance agenda, which focuses on improving local planning and budgeting systems, 
strengthening intergovernmental fiscal relations, and strengthening local service delivery.11 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact of the TA is that poor, vulnerable, and disadvantaged individuals, families, and 
communities empowered and protected from risks. The outcome of the TA is DSWD capacity to 
implement NCDDP enhanced. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The outputs of the TA are (i) identified options for improved policy and institutional framework 
for implementing NCDDP; (ii) identified options for strengthened resource allocation, funds flow, and 
accountability  mechanisms;  (iii)  enhanced  capacities  of  stakeholders  in  the  provinces;  and  (iv) 
supported pilot-testing of NCDDP design elements related to PLGU engagement.  
 
11.  Identified options for improved policy and institutional framework for implementing 
NCDDP. Under the TA, analytical work will be conducted and recommendations delivered to 
provide the enabling mechanisms for PLGUs to (i) have a more pronounced role in defining 
province-wide strategic priorities and in leveraging their political and financial resources to align 
the local activities of their component LGUs; (ii) serve as primary partners of sector NGAs in 
monitoring the performance of component LGUs according to prescribed service standards, while 
linking these to DILG measures to improve LGU performance; (iii) engage NGAs and component 
LGUs to implement an integrated and harmonized community development platform; (iv) improve 
inter-and intragovernment links and strengthen convergence of social development programs at 
the  provincial  level;  (v)  improve  resource  allocation  and  expenditure  management;  and  (vi) 
strengthen  multisector  partnerships  at  the  provincial  level.  Along  with  the  analytical  work, 
government issuances such as executive orders, departmental orders, administrative orders, 
memorandum circulars, and LGU resolutions will be drafted as needed. 
 
12.  Identified  options  for  strengthened  resource  allocation,  funds  flow,  and 
accountability mechanisms. Central to the success of the NCDDP are the resource allocation 
mechanisms and fiduciary arrangements for channeling funds to the communities.  Funding 
arrangements for the NCDDP will (i) ensure community participation; (ii) promote transparency 
and  accountability;  (iii)  prevent  irregularities  and  misuse;  (iv)  avoid  social  exclusion  and 
leakages  to  the  non-poor;  (v)  ensure  synchronization  and  harmonization  of  planning, 
programming, budgeting, and auditing systems; and (vi) ensure long-term resource flows for 
CDD subprojects. In this regard, the TA will identify options and mechanisms for channeling, 
accessing, managing, and disbursing financial resources from PLGUs, MLGUs, and NGAs to 
the communities. The TA will also support the institutionalization of participatory planning and 
budgeting processes to rationalize resource allocation decisions. In addition, the TA will assist in 
streamlining procurement and logistics management processes for CDD subprojects.  
 
13.  Enhanced  capacities  of  stakeholders  in  the  provinces.  Under  the  TA,  expert 
assistance  and  institutional  support  will  be  provided  to  (i)  establishing  mechanisms  for 
managing the training needs of officials and staff of selected PLGUs and MLGUs, CDD field 
staff, grassroots leaders, and community volunteers; (ii) establishing mechanisms for providing 
facilitation and technical support to the PLGUs and communities during the transition phase of 
NCDDP implementation, including managing institutional risks; (iii) training CDD trainers and 
facilitators  in  selected  provinces;  and  (iv)  implementing  a  comprehensive  communications 
strategy to mobilize support to PLGU engagement in the NCDDP.  
 
14.  Supported pilot-testing of NCDDP design elements related to PLGU engagement. 
The TA will support the testing of NCDDP design elements in selected PLGUs to identify areas 
for improvement. The criteria and guidelines for selecting the PLGUs will be developed during 
TA inception. The TA will also support the development and enhancement of a monitoring and 
evaluation system for the NCDDP to ensure timely and accurate feedback during the pilot and 
transition phases. Under the TA, the results of the pilot testing will be used to (i) consolidate the 
design and content of the NCDPP; (ii) strengthen the policy framework, resource flows, and 
implementation  arrangements,  particularly  with  regard  to  PLGU  engagement;  (iii)  assign 
NCDDP  functions  unambiguously  to  different  stakeholders;  and  (iv)  improve  operational

5 
guidelines and manuals. The pilot testing will provide opportunities for local actors to participate 
in the design process and, in the process, will generate local ownership and support. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-other sources) in the amount of $800,000. The government will provide counterpart 
support in terms of remuneration of counterpart staff, office accommodation, utilities, and other 
in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The DSWD will be the executing agency and will implement the TA under the direct 
supervision and guidance of the DSWD secretary. A steering committee chaired by the DSWD 
secretary and composed of senior officials from the DSWD and participating national and local 
government agencies will oversee TA implementation, provide quality assurance, and extend 
policy  and  program  direction  to  ensure  effective  coordination  with  the  HDPRC,  other 
government bodies, development partners, and stakeholders. The implementing agencies will 
include the NCDDP preparation team, NCDDP interagency preparation team, and participating 
PLGUs and MLGUs.  
 
17.  ADB will engage consultants through a combination of individual consultants’ selection 
and consultants’ qualifications selection in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference for 15 person-
months  of  international  consulting  services  and  48  person-months  of  national  consulting 
services are in Appendix 3. To provide the TA with flexibility to mobilize expertise as the 
NCDDP  evolves,  the  terms  of  reference  and  selection  method  for  6  person-months  of 
international  consulting  services  and  24  person-months  of  national  consulting  services—
possibly  in  the  areas  of  public  sector  management,  national  government  accounting,  and 
community development—will be determined during project implementation. All procurement will 
be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). All procured assets will be transferred to the executing agency after the completion of the 
TA.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented from 1 August 2012 to 31 July 2015. TA supervision and 
review missions will be regularly conducted. The expected outputs, outcome evaluation, lessons 
learned, and methodologies developed under the TA will be disseminated through government 
websites, seminars, conferences, and print media.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Philippines for Enhancing Social Protection through Community-Driven 
Development Approach, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  the  Department  of  Social  Work  and 
Development (DSWD) in the design and implementation of the National Community Driven 
Development Program (NCDDP). The outputs of the TA are (i) improved policy and institutional 
framework  for  implementing  the  NCDDP  at  the  provincial  level;  (ii)  strengthened  resource 
allocation, funds flow, and accountability mechanisms; (iii) enhanced awareness and capacities 
of stakeholders in the provinces; and (iv) supported pilot-testing of NCDDP design elements 
related to provincial local government unit (PLGU) engagement.  
 
2.  To be implemented over a period of 3 years, the TA will require 15 person-months of 
international consulting services and 48 person-months of national consulting services. Four 
consultants will be recruited using individual consultant selection and two consultants will be 
recruited through two firms using consultants’ qualifications selection method. Some flexibility in 
the mobilization of consultants will be required to accommodate DSWD priorities in view of the 
evolving nature of the NCDDP. As such, about 6 person-months of international and 24 person-
months of national consulting services in the areas of public sector management, national 
government  accounting,  and  community  development  will  be  determined  during  project 
implementation. All consultants will report to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) project officer 
and coordinate with the DSWD on the substance and timing of the consultants’ deliverables.  
 
B.  Individual Consultants 
 
3.  Since the TA will require highly specialized expertise covering a broad range of areas 
and, considering that most assignments will be relatively small and on intermittent basis, the 
consultants  for  the  following  positions  will  be  recruited  individually:  (i)  community-driven 
development (CDD) specialist and lead expert, (ii) fiduciary management expert, (iii) social 
development specialist, and (iv) governance and institutional development specialist.   
 
1.   Community-Driven Development Specialist and Lead Expert (international, 9 
person-months, intermittent) 
 
4.  The expert should have a postgraduate degree in social science, public administration, 
management, political science, or a related discipline. The position requires at least 15 years of 
experience in poverty reduction and participatory development, particularly in managing social 
development  programs  with  CDD  features.  The  expert  should  have  a  solid  conceptual 
understanding of CDD and local development, and be familiar with working with multilateral 
development banks. The indicative tasks of the expert are as follows:  
(i)  provide  expert  guidance  in  strengthening  the  overall  program  design,  policy 
framework,  financial  and  management  systems,  and  operations  manual  to 
support the scaling up of CDD;  
(ii)  undertake  critical  analysis  of  the  policy  and  institutional  framework  for  the 
effective engagement of PLGUs in the NCDDP and draft required amendments 
or legal instruments;  
(iii)  recommend  necessary  policy  reforms  and  design  institutional  structures  and 
arrangements to facilitate engagement of PLGUs, including sector departments, 
in the NCDDP;

Appendix 3  11 
(iv)  develop  a  PLGU–NCDDP  manual  that  contains  detailed  instructions  on 
processes and procedures to be followed during CDD subproject identification, 
planning, preparation, procurement, implementation, and monitoring phases;  
(v)  develop model CDD subproject agreements and other standardized documents;  
(vi)  oversee,  coordinate,  and  provide  quality  assurance  to  the  work  of  other 
consultants;  
(vii)  identify constraints on effective implementation of the NCDDP and recommend 
measures to address them;  
(viii)  coordinate TA implementation with ADB, DSWD, and other government agencies 
and development partners;  
(ix)  provide professional advice on various NCDDP issues; and  
(x)  ensure timely submission of TA outputs and reports. 
 
2.    Fiduciary Management Expert (international, 6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
5.  The expert should have a postgraduate degree in finance, accounting, or a related field. 
The expert should have at least 10 years of experience in budgeting and managing finances of 
public investment projects, including foreign-assisted projects and community block grants. The 
position requires solid knowledge of the government’s budgeting, investment programming, 
financial management, public procurement, and auditing systems. Experience in the Philippines 
would be an advantage. The indicative tasks of the experts are as follows:  
(i)  conduct a comprehensive review of existing legal, regulatory, and institutional 
frameworks affecting PLGU financing of CDD subprojects;  
(ii)  provide  technical  guidance  in  strengthening  fiduciary  arrangements  and 
accountability mechanisms;  
(iii)  develop an operations manual on financial management and procurement; and  
(iv)  develop an inventory of funding sources for CDD subprojects at the provincial 
level. 
 
3.    Social Development Specialist (national, 12 person-months, intermittent)   
 
6.  The  specialist  requires  a  postgraduate  degree  in  anthropology,  international 
development, social development, political science, public policy, sociology, or related fields 
with at least 10 years of relevant professional experience in the field of social development, 
community-driven development, social accountability, regional and/or local development, social 
protection, or gender and development. The indicative tasks of the specialist are as follows:  
(i)  provide technical guidance to reducing poverty; improving social inclusiveness; 
and  addressing  risk,  vulnerability  and  inequality;  and  promote  participatory 
development in project design and implementation;  
(ii)  ensure that social dimensions are incorporated in the design of the project;  
(iii)  design and enhance the complaints and grievance system of PLGUs for NCDDP 
implementation; and  
(iv)  identify measures to facilitate the convergence of social development programs 
at the provincial level.  
 
4.   Governance  and  Institutional  Development Specialist  (national, 3 person-
months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The  position  requires  a  postgraduate  degree  in  public  administration,  management, 
social science, or a related discipline with at least 10 years of work experience in institution

12          Appendix 3   
 
building and managing administrative reforms. The indicative tasks of the specialist are as 
follows:  
(i)  provide expert guidance in putting in place and strengthening organization and 
management structures, institutional links and coordination, and administrative 
processes to support PLGU engagement in the NCDDP;  
(ii)  help PLGUs strengthen knowledge management functions and institutionalize 
CDD operations in PLGU governance systems;  
(iii)  assist PLGUs establish mechanisms to provide continuous facilitation support 
and technical guidance to the field throughout the different stages of NCDDP 
implementation; 
(iv)  help establish institutional mechanisms to strengthen multisector partnerships 
and interagency collaboration;   
(v)  help develop an incentive system to mobilize PLGU support to the NCDDP; and  
(vi)  design and implement a communications plan to raise public awareness of the 
NCDDP.  
 
C.  Consulting Firms 
 
8.  The capacity development specialists and the monitoring and evaluation (M&E) expert 
will be recruited through two consulting firms—one will lead the TA’s capacity development 
component and the other will implement the TA’s M&E component, including the conduct of 
studies and surveys. They will closely coordinate their work with the individual consultants hired 
under the TA. 
 
1.   Capacity Development Component (national consultants, 21 person-months, 
intermittent inputs) 
 
9.  The specialized capacity development and training entity will provide the following inputs: 
(i) conduct capacity development needs assessment; (ii) develop training manuals; (iii) help 
address the training needs of CDD clients in the province; (iv) organize, oversee, and administer 
training programs; and (v) provide facilitation and technical support services in the field. The firm 
will provide experience in enhancing CDD knowledge and skills of government, civil society, and 
community stakeholders. The specialists will be deployed in different geographical locations but 
will be expected to provide coherent capacity development interventions. It is expected that at 
least three experts will be required to provide the services.   
 
2.   Monitoring  and  Evaluation  Component  (national  consultant,  12  person-
months, intermittent) 
 
10.  The  consultant  is  expected  to  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  economics,  public 
administration, management, or a related field, with at least 10 years of work experience in the 
design and management of M&E systems of government-financed and foreign-assisted social 
development programs. The indicative tasks of the consultant are as follows:  
(i)  provide technical guidance in the development of strengthening an M&E system 
to monitor progress and evaluate the impacts of the NCDDP, particularly at the 
provincial level;  
(ii)  identify, document, and disseminate best practices;  
(iii)  administer required surveys and studies; and 
(iv)  ensure that relevant information on the NCDDP is recorded and disseminated.
